cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 170, Number 30 (Thursday, February 15, 2024)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. MILLER of Ohio:H.R. 7386.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:This bill is enacted pursuant to the power granted toCongress under Article I, Section 8 of the United StatesConstitution.The single subject of this legislation is:The single subject of this bill is to create publicawareness of career and technical education.[Page H680]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

bill.title: Career and Technical Education Advocacy Grant Program Act

item.title: Career and Technical Education Advocacy Grant Program Act
Career and Technical Education Advocacy Grant Program Act
To establish a grant program to support career and technical education schools in their efforts to advocate for career and technical education programs and promote public awareness thereof.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Education and the Workforce.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
